cards.title: Athletics / On the Wall: Turia Pitt's courage and the strength of the human spirit – short film
cards.rawTitle: On the Wall: Turia Pitt's courage and the strength of the human spirit – short film

item.title: On the Wall: Turia Pitt's courage and the strength of the human spirit – short film
item.trailText: On the Wall is the remarkable story of Turia Pitt, who suffered burns to 65% of her body during Western Australia's 2011 ultramarathon
item.standFirst: In 2011 Turia Pitt was burnt in a bushfire during an ultramarathon and suffered burns to 65% of her body. Many thought she wouldn't survive. Now, after years of recovery, Turia is walking the Great Wall of China to raise money for the medical organisation Interplast. In this short film, Turia shows just what the human spirit is capable of with courage, strength and an incredible sense of humour. Shot and directed by Dave Zwolenski of Real Good Kid Productions, On the Wall was a finalist in the Australian shorts category at the Human Rights Arts and Film festival

cards.title: Rugby league / NSW captain Paul Gallen slams Qld as 'grubby', 'disrespectful'
cards.rawTitle: NSW captain Paul Gallen slams Qld as 'grubby', 'disrespectful'

item.title: NSW captain Paul Gallen slams Qld as 'grubby', 'disrespectful'
item.trailText: Paul Gallen has set the scene for an explosive State of Origin II, after labelling Queensland “disrespectful” and “grubby” in his final press conference before the MCG showpiece.
item.standFirst: • Returning captain Gallen raises the temperature ahead of Origin Game II
item.body:
Paul Gallen has set the scene for an explosive State of Origin II, after labelling Queensland "disrespectful" and "grubby" in his final press conference before Wednesday’s MCG showpiece.

In one of the most entertaining and pointed media conferences of the season, the Blues skipper claimed on Tuesday the Maroons were showing NSW no respect carrying an injured Billy Slater into game two.

Gallen also spoke again of what he labelled the Maroons’ "grubby" tactics in their win in Origin I last month and said the Blues had a firm plan to combat anything Queensland threw their way in game two.

"We have been used to their grubby tactics for years now, in game one I suppose the boys were a bit naive to think that some of the so-called angels of the game don’t get up to any of it," Gallen said.

"I’m sure that none of the boys will take a backward step this time, they know what is coming and I’m sure Queensland do as well.

"We are not out there to fight, we are not out there to play dirty, we are out there to play hard and tough but we won’t be taking any a backward step and if those tactics start to sneak into the game I’m sure our boys will adapt to that."

Gallen again identified Nate Myles as the Maroons’ chief niggler in the Blues’ eyes, and said Slater putting "his shoulder into" Josh Morris as he lay on the ground in game one, was among several incidents that upset NSW.

The Blues are also incensed by news Slater is set for season-ending surgery on his shoulder, the day after Origin II.

"If he is planning on having surgery on Thursday, I think that is a sign of where their team is at the moment," Gallen said.

"They think they are that much better than us, they think they are going to get this win and it is going to be the end of the series and Billy is going to get surgery and have the rest of the year off.

"It is a little bit disrespectful to us, but it is easy to be talking about it and having a go at him. We have to go out there and get the win tomorrow night and prove that we are the better side."

displayImages.credit: Michael Dodge/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Paul Gallen

headerImage.caption: Returning NSW captain Paul Gallen, seen here during training, has lit the tinder ahead of the crunch-clash Game II of State of Origin in Melbourne. Photograph: Michael Dodge/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Returning NSW captain Paul Gallen, seen here during training, has lit the tinder ahead of the crunch-clash Game II of State of Origin in Melbourne.

snap.title: NSW captain Paul Gallen slams Qld as 'grubby', 'disrespectful'

image.credit: Michael Dodge/Getty Images
image.altText: Paul Gallen

cards.title: Snooker / Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
cards.rawTitle: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion

item.title: Snooker, chess and bridge among sports to apply for 2020 Olympics inclusion
item.trailText: Tug of war and baseball are also among a list of 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Games, before a shortlist is announced on 26 June
item.standFirst:
• Tug of war and baseball also among 26 sports to have applied for Tokyo Games
• Shortlist will be announced on 26 June before final decision next August
item.body:
Snooker, chess, bridge and tug of war are among the 26 sports to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.

Baseball and softball have also applied, as has squash, after they were the sports to miss out when wrestling was reinstated by the International Olympic Committee in 2013 having initially been dropped for 2020.

Squash will be hoping to be included for the first time after missing out to golf and rugby sevens for the 2016 Games while baseball and softball, popular in Japan, is bidding to return having been dropped following Beijing 2008.

The Tokyo 2020 additional event programme panel will now narrow the 26 applicants down to a shortlist to be announced on 22 June, with a final decision due to be made by the IOC in August next year.

The decision will be made based on whether the applicant can “serve as a driving force to promote the Olympic movement and its values, with a focus on youth appeal” and “add value to the Games by engaging the Japanese population and new audiences worldwide, reflecting the Tokyo 2020 Games vision”.

The traditional Japanese sport of sumo has also lodged an application as have karate, American football, tenpin bowling, polo and orienteering.

Full list of federations to have applied for inclusion in the 2020 Olympic Games

World Air Sports Federation (FAI), International Federation of American Football (IFAF), World Baseball Softball Confederation (WBSC), World Confederation of Billiards Sports (WCBS), Bowls Sports World Confederation (CMSB), World Bowling (WB), World Bridge Federation (WBF), World Chess Federation (FIDE), World DanceSport Federation (WDSF), International Floorball Federation (IFF), World Flying Disc Federation (WFDF), World Karate Federation (WKF), International Korfball Federation (IKF), International Netball Federation (INF), International Orienteering Federation (IOF), Federation of International Polo (FIP), International Racquetball Federation (IRF), International Federation of Roller Sports (FIRS), International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC), World Squash Federation (WSF), International Sumo Federation (IFS), International Surfing Association (ISA), Tug of War International Federation (TWIF), World Underwater Federation (CMAS), International Waterski & Wakeboard Federation (IWWF), International Wushu Federation (IWUF).

cards.title: US sports / Jordan Spieth aims to join elite group by adding US Open to Masters title
cards.rawTitle: Jordan Spieth aims to join elite group by adding US Open to Masters title

item.title: Jordan Spieth aims to join elite group by adding US Open to Masters title
item.trailText: Jordan Spieth knows he can make history in ‘many ways’ this year and even has one eye on an unprecedented clean sweep of the four major championships
item.standFirst:
• ‘I have a chance to make history in many ways,’ says 21-year-old
• Hopes to become only sixth man to win US Open and Masters in same year
item.body:
Jordan Spieth knows he can make history in “many ways” this year and even has one eye on an unprecedented clean sweep of the four major championships.

Spieth is looking to become just the sixth man in history after Craig Wood, Ben Hogan, Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods to win the Masters and US Open in the same year.

And the world No2 can also became the first player since Gene Sarazen in 1922 to win multiple majors aged 21 or younger with victory at Chambers Bay.

Related: Martin Kaymer: ‘There is no lead that is really big enough for you to relax’ | Ewan Murray

“I have a chance to make history in many ways,” said Spieth, who has recorded nine top-10 finishes on the PGA Tour this season. “But in order to do that, I have to really focus on this week, focus on the major championships and how I’m going to prepare for them. There are certainly a lot of goals left for the year.

“It’s never even crossed my mind to let it kind of sink in that it’s been a great year, and that it would be a great year at the end. If I didn’t do anything the rest of the year, I’d be pretty frustrated at the second half.

“You can’t win a Grand Slam unless you win the first [major], so I’m the only one with that opportunity this year. So I’m going to go ahead and focus on this week and see if I can put myself in contention.”

Chambers Bay has received mixed reviews from the players with the former Masters champion Charl Schwartzel saying luck will play a big part in the fast, dry conditions which were compared to the 2013 Open at Muirfield by local favourite Ryan Moore.

Related: Jason Day believes matters of the mind are holding back Tiger Woods

Much has also been made of how the numerous tees will see the course set-up changed each day, with the first and 18th capable of being played as either a par four or par five.

“To be honest, I think it’s more just to get in our heads ahead of time,” added Spieth, who approved of the changes made to the course since he shot 83 here in the 2010 US Amateur.

“I think if the wind is coming from the north, we’re going to play the first as par five and 18 as a par four. If it’s the other way, it’ll be the other way. Twelve is probably going to be a similar tee box every day.

“Fifteen has an opportunity to change drastically, but if the greens are where the USGA wants the greens to be, I don’t think that 245-yard tee box can or should be played. The way that green pitches, it would have to be a back left pin or else we’re never going to finish the round. And they know that.

“In the 2010 US Amateur, there was a lot learned from us and from the USGA and so I think they have a great grasp on what they’re going to do with the golf course.”

cards.title: Australia sport / Australia’s pace bowlers hard to whittle down for Ashes, says Darren Lehmann
cards.rawTitle: Australia’s pace bowlers hard to whittle down for Ashes, says Darren Lehmann

item.title: Australia’s pace bowlers hard to whittle down for Ashes, says Darren Lehmann
item.trailText: Australia coach Darren Lehmann is delighted to be wrestling with a dilemma over which three of five pace bowlers will start the Ashes series against England next month
item.standFirst:
• ‘Those guys have given us a massive headache,’ says Australia coach
• ‘Two of those five are going to be unbelievably unlucky to miss out’
item.body:
The Australia coach, Darren Lehmann, is delighted to be wrestling with a dilemma over which three of five pace bowlers will start the Ashes series against England in Cardiff next month.

The tourists will leave the Caribbean for Britain on Tuesday charged with confidence after completing a convincing 2-0 sweep of West Indies with a 277-run victory in the second Test.

The right-arm quick Josh Hazlewood was named Australia’s ’man of the series’ after taking 12 wickets at 8.83 over the two matches, including his second five-wicket haul in only five Tests for his country.

The Left-armer Mitch Starc continued where he left off with the white ball at the World Cup, where he was named ’man of the tournament’, by taking 10 wickets at 16 apiece against West Indies.

The reigning ICC Cricketer of the Year, Mitchell Johnson (seven wickets at 18.62 in the series), and Peter Siddle are also in the party and the injury-prone but often explosive Ryan Harris is set to join the squad in England.

“Those guys have given us a massive headache – albeit a good one – and we have a really tough decision to make when it comes to picking the side for the first Test in Cardiff,” he wrote in a column on the Cricket Australia website.

“Two of those five guys are going to be unbelievably unlucky to miss out, but that’s what happens when you’re playing good cricket. You have to make those hard decisions. We just have to pick the right three fast bowlers to take the 20 wickets in that first Test.

“And that’s not to say we’ll play those three all series, but we’ll just pick the XI for that match and go from there.“

Hazlewood has never bowled a red ball in anger in English conditions and will be keen to prove he can generate pace and bounce on the grassy pitches there as he did on the sluggish Caribbean tracks.

The 24-year-old will have his chance when Australia play four-day tour matches against Kent and Essex in the runup to the first test on 8 July.

“The two tour matches leading into the series will play a big part in our thinking,” Lehmann added.

“We need to see how the bowlers pull up and how they bowl in the different conditions, on different pitches and with the different ball.“

Overall, there is no doubt Australia are in much better shape than when Lehmann led them to England for the first time in 2013 after a 4-0 humiliation in India and the sacking of Mickey Arthur. They lost 3-0.

“We’re not far off but we know we have to raise the bar to win over there,” Lehmann said. “We haven’t done it for 14 years and that’s our goal.”

displayImages.caption: Josh Hazlewood was voted Australia's man of the series over the two matches against West Indies but English conditions would be a new test for the 24-year-old.  Photograph: Robyn Beck/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.credit: Robyn Beck/AFP/Getty Images

cards.title: Olympic Games 2016 / USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens
cards.rawTitle: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens

item.title: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens
item.trailText: Men beat North American rivals 21-5 to win Nacra Sevens title while Canadians must now qualify from world repechage event next year
item.standFirst:
• Men beat North American rivals 21-5 to win Nacra Sevens title
  • Canadians must now qualify from world repechage event next year
item.body:
The USA men’s and women’s sevens teams booked their places at the Rio Olympic Games on Sunday, by winning their respective titles at the Nacra Sevens in Cary, North Carolina.

Both teams strolled through the qualifying matches against exponentially weaker opposition from the Caribbean and Central America, and Ric Suggitt’s women completed their task by crushing Mexico 88-0 in the final.

Mike Friday’s men, who last month won their first HSBC Sevens World Series title in London, were given a tougher task at WakeMed Soccer Park, facing keen rivals Canada in the decider.

First-half tries from Perry Baker, Danny Barrett and Maka Unufe, all converted by captain Madison Hughes, established a 21-0 lead at the break in the 20-minute final. Folau Niua was shown a yellow card shortly before the turnaround, but Mike Friday’s team survived his absence, showing strong resolve in defence.

Harry Jones scored a second-half try for Canada to close the gap, although Nathan Hirayama sent the conversion off the post. The USA’s Saracens back Chris Wyles, brought into the squad for the tournament as its only member not training full time at the Olympic centre in California, was shown another yellow card as the clock ran down. But it was too late for Canada to come back.

Canada, who fielded a strong squad for Nacra, must now attempt to qualify for Rio – at which rugby, albeit in its shortened form, will return to the Games for the first time since 1924 – at a global repechage event to be staged next year.

Each Olympic tournament will feature 12 teams. In the men’s game, the US join the top four World Series finishers – Fiji, South Africa, New Zealand and England (who booked a spot in Rio for Great Britain) – plus hosts Brazil and South American qualifiers Argentina in confirming their place at the Games. European qualifying continues this month, with France the clear favourites to progress.

Canada’s women had already qualified for Rio through the World Series, with New Zealand, Australia and England. Those teams and Brazil have now been joined by the US and Colombia in the draw for the Olympic event.

Asia, Africa and Oceania will decide their automatic qualifiers in tournaments held later this year.

The USA are the reigning Olympic rugby champions, having won 15-a-side gold in Paris 91 years ago. They also won gold in Antwerp in 1920.

displayImages.credit: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Danny Barrett, Madison Hughes

headerImage.caption: Danny Barrett and Madison Hughes, shown here celebrating in London last month, were among the points scorers in Cary, North Carolina. Photograph: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Danny Barrett and Madison Hughes, shown here celebrating in London last month, were among the points scorers in Cary, North Carolina.

snap.title: USA men beat Canada to join women in Rio Olympic Games rugby sevens

image.credit: Christopher Lee/Getty Images
image.altText: Danny Barrett, Madison Hughes

item.title: Volvo Ocean Race: stage eight
item.trailText: The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France.
item.standFirst:
The best pictures from the eighth leg of the 2014-15 Volvo Ocean Race, from Lisbon in Portugal to Lorient in France. The race covers 39,379 nautical miles and will visit 11 ports in 11 countries over nine months.

image.caption: Onboard Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, Louis Sinclair and Luke Parkinson carry the J1 off the bow as winds die off Portugal Photograph: M Knighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: M Knighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image

image.caption: A pod of Portuguese dolphins blow off some early morning energy in the water next to the Team Alvimedica yacht Photograph: Amory Ross/Team Alvimedica via Getty Images

image.caption: Onboard Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing, Louis Sinclair and Simon “SiFi” Fisher pump on the main halyard as the team shakes a reef in the Bay of Biscay Photograph: MKnighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: MKnighton/Abu Dhabi Ocean Racing/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image

image.caption: A big wave of water pours over the top of the watch team of Xabi Fernandez, Antonio Cuervas - Mons ‘eti’ and Willy Altadill onboard MAPFRE Photograph: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image
image.credit: Francisco Vignale/MAPFRE/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Image

image.caption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.altText: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage
image.cleanCaption: Team SCA are the first team into Lorient, France and win the stage in a time of 3 days, 13 hours, 11 minutes and 11 seconds
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rick Tomlinson/Team SCA/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images

image.caption: One hour, 26 minutes and 35 seconds later the Dongfeng Race Team was the final yacht to arrive in Lorient to finish in seventh place Photograph: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
image.credit: Ricardo Pinto/Volvo Ocean Race via Getty Images
